items.title: Right to be informed
items.description: Organisations must clearly tell you what personal data they collect, why, who they share it with, and how long they keep it.

items.title: Right of access
items.description: You can request a copy of your personal data held by any organisation (normally free, within one month).

items.title: Right to rectification
items.description: If information about you is inaccurate or incomplete, you can ask for it to be corrected or updated.

items.title: Right to erasure (‘right to be forgotten’)
items.description: You can request that your personal data be deleted in certain circumstances (for example, where consent is withdrawn, data is no longer necessary, or it was unlawfully processed).

items.title: Right to restrict processing
items.description: You can limit how an organisation uses your personal data while a complaint or request is being resolved.

items.title: Right to data portability
items.description: You can request to receive your personal data in a machine-readable format and/or have it transferred directly to another provider.

items.title: Right to object
items.description: You can object to certain uses of your data, including direct marketing, research, or profiling.

items.title: Rights related to automated decision-making
items.description: You are protected against decisions made solely by automated processing (including profiling) that significantly affect you, with limited exceptions.

items.title: Right to complain
items.description: If you believe your data protection rights have been infringed, you can complain to the Data Protection Commission (DPC) in Ireland.

items.title: Right to seek compensation
items.description: If you suffer material or non-material damage due to a GDPR infringement, you may be entitled to compensation through the courts.
